title-group.article-title: Genome-wide identification and characterization of DUF789 genes in cotton: implications for fibre development

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Proteins containing domains of unknown function (DUFs) play a crucial role in plant growth, development and stress adaptation, but many of them are still uncharacterized. The DUF789 family is one of the least studied of these, especially in economically significant crops like cotton (Gossypium spp.), whose possible function in fibre production and abiotic stress response is yet unknown.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In a comprehensive genome-wide analysis, a total of 91 DUF789 genes were identified in four Gossypium species: G. arboreum, G. barbadense, G. raimondii and G. hirsutum. Evolutionary and phylogenetic analyses placed the GhDUF789 proteins into different clades, with purifying selection identified as the major evolutionary force. Analyses of gene structure and conserved motifs revealed considerable structural diversity, with closely related genes showing similar exon–intron patterns and motif compositions. Synteny and duplication analyses showed that segmental and tandem duplications contributed to the DUF789 family expansion in cotton. Analysis of cis-regulatory elements revealed that the GhDUF789 promoters are enriched in motifs responsive to hormonal, developmental, light-induced and abiotic stresses. GO enrichment analyses, prediction of protein–protein interaction and secondary and tertiary structure modelling, indicated that GhDUF789 proteins are involved in clathrin-mediated vesicle trafficking and membrane trafficking. The miRNA target prediction revealed regulatory interactions with conserved miRNAs from cotton, in particular ghr-miR414 and ghr-miR396. Expression profiling based on transcriptome analysis, supported by validation using qRT-PCR, revealed that several GhDUF789 genes are differentially expressed during fibre development and respond strongly to drought, heat, salinity and cold stress, especially in drought-tolerant genotypes.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study provides the first comprehensive characterization of the DUF789 gene family in cotton and offers new insights into its evolutionary dynamics, structural features and potential role in fibre development and adaptation to abiotic stress. The results provide a solid foundation for future functional studies and identify candidate GhDUF789 genes for targeted genetic improvement of stress resistance and fibre quality in cotton.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12870-025-07258-3.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent decades, the integration of genomics, transcriptomics and proteomics has greatly improved our understanding of plant biology and facilitated the discovery and functional characterization of key genes involved in development, adaptation and stress response [1]. These multi-omics approaches have also accelerated the identification of gene families in diverse plant species, revealing conserved regulatory elements and species-specific expansions [2, 3]. Despite these advances, a considerable proportion of plant genes remain poorly characterized [4, 5]. These include proteins with domains of unknown function (DUFs), a broad class of evolutionarily conserved domains without a clearly defined biological function [6]. Chris Ponting was the first to identify and label these domains as DUF1 and DUF2 in 1998 [7]. Since then, genome sequencing efforts have led to the identification of many more DUF families. The Pfam version 35.0, database consists of 19,632 families, of which 4,795 are classified as DUFs [8]. In particular, DUF-containing proteins - especially those with DUF231, DUF1218 and DUF724 domains have been functionally linked to important aspects of plant development [9].

Recent studies on model species such as A. thaliana and O. sativa have provided initial insights into the possible functions of several DUF families. For example, in A. thaliana, TBL3 and TBR, which encode DUF231 domain-containing proteins, are essential for secondary cell wall biosynthesis [10, 11]. Since cellulose is a major component of plant cell walls, proteins with DUF266 domains are thought to be involved in their biosynthesis and may function as glycosyltransferases [12]. Disruption of DUF266 genes in rice led to a significant reduction in cellulose content [13]. In A. thaliana, six genes of the RUS family encoded proteins that contained a DUF647 domain. Of these, RUS1 and RUS2 are essential for early seedling development, vitamin B6 homeostasis and auxin transport [14], while RUS6 has broad developmental expression, especially in flowers, indicating its evolutionary importance in A. thaliana [15]. Similarly, Vergès et al. (2023) reported the expression of 23 DUF genes in the reproductive organs of A. thaliana, with most of them localized in the endosperm [16]. The DUF239 genes show different expression patterns, suggesting a specialized role for neprosin-related proteins, especially during seed maturation. The role of DUF gene families in abiotic stress responses in rice and A. thaliana has also been thoroughly studied [17].

The expression of DUF genes is also influenced by abiotic stress and phytohormonal signaling pathways [18]. For example, the Arabidopsis genes AtRDUF1 and AtRDUF2 are upregulated by abscisic acid (ABA) and drought, and their reduced expression impairs drought tolerance [19]. Transgenic A. thaliana plants overexpressing the salt-responsive gene TaSRHP (DUF581) show increased tolerance to salt stress [20]. Similarly, overexpression of the transcription factor TaSRG (DUF662) improves salt tolerance in both rice and A. thaliana [21]. In rice, OsDUF6 is crucial for salt stress tolerance [22], whereas overexpression of a DUF-containing gene from alfalfa (MsDUF) negatively affects osmotic stress responses in transgenic tobacco [23]. The DUF221 and ATDUF4228 domains have also been strongly associated with ABA-mediated abiotic stress responses [18, 20, 24, 25]. A comprehensive analysis of BrDUF506 genes across the Brassica rapa genome has revealed a possible role in sexual reproduction and abiotic stress tolerance [26]. Taken together, these results emphasize the functional versatility and physiological importance of DUF-containing genes in the regulation of plant growth, development and environmental adaptation. However, except a few well-characterized families, the biological functions of most DUF domains including DUF789, remain poorly understood and require further investigation.

The DUF789 family has received little attention in the scientific literature. Although it has been listed in the major protein domain databases and identified in several plant genomes, its functional characterization is still largely unexplored. In A. thaliana, several DUF789 genes are expressed in reproductive organs, including flowers and developing seeds, suggesting a possible role in organ development or fertility [27]. However, few mechanistic studies have addressed their molecular functions, subcellular localizations, or roles in specific signaling pathways. Moreover, no comprehensive analysis has been performed on polyploid crops, leaving a significant gap in our understanding of their evolutionary diversification, regulatory mechanisms and potential contributions to agronomically important traits.

Bridging this knowledge gap is particularly important for economically important species, where improved annotation of poorly characterized gene families could support targeted breeding strategies. One such polyploid crop in which DUF789 genes are still completely unexplored is cotton (G. hirsutum), the world’s leading natural fiber crop. G. hirsutum is an allotetraploid species (AADD, 2n = 4x = 52) resulting from the hybridization of two diploid ancestors, G. arboreum (A genome) and G. raimondii (D genome) [28]. Their genomic complexity poses a challenge for the characterization of gene families, but also provides an ideal system for the study of gene duplication, sub functionalization and neofunctionalization [29]. Cotton fiber development undergoes tightly regulated stages during cell initiation, elongation, secondary wall deposition, and maturation, and is controlled by a complex network of structural and regulatory genes, many of which remain poorly characterized. While other DUF families have been implicated in cotton stress responses [30], a genome-wide characterization of the DUF789 gene family in cotton has not yet been performed. To fill this gap, we performed the first genome-wide characterization of the DUF789 gene family in four cotton species: in the two cultivated allotetraploids Gossypium hirsutum and G. barbadense, as well as in their diploid ancestors G. arboreum (A genome) and G. raimondii (D genome). The inclusion of the diploid ancestors allowed us to trace the evolutionary origin, expansion and divergence of DUF789 genes before polyploidization, while comparative analyses of the tetraploids provided insights into gene retention, duplication and probable neofunctionalisation. We systematically identified DUF789 genes in all four species and analysed their gene structures, conserved motifs, phylogenetic relationships and chromosomal distributions.

sec.title: Materials and methods
GhDUF789 gene family identification
sec.p: The genome annotation and reference sequence datasets for the tetraploid cotton species Gossypium barbadense (version 1.1) and G. hirsutum (version 2.1) and their diploid ancestors G. raimondii and G. arboreum (both version 2.1) are from the CottonMD database (https://yanglab.hzau.edu.cn/CottonMD/download.1) [31]. All of the DUF789 gene family’s (AtDUF789) annotated protein sequences in Arabidopsis thaliana were retrieved from the Arabidopsis Information Resource (TAIR) portal (https://www.arabidopsis.org/). The Pfam database (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/interpro/entry/pfam/) was used to identify the members of the GhDUF789 gene family corresponding to Pfam ID PF05623 [32], and the Hidden Markov Model (HMM) profile was downloaded accordingly. The Pfam database (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/interpro/entry/pfam/) was used to identify the members of the GhDUF789 gene family corresponding to Pfam ID PF05623. This was specifically selected as it represents the only curated and widely accepted HMM profile for the DUF789 domain. This domain model was derived from a high quality multiple sequence alignment of DUF789-containing proteins from various eukaryotic lineages, including plants, and is considered the standard for DUF789 annotation in current genomic studies [6]. Although the biological function of the DUF789 domain has not yet been characterized, PF05623 provides the most comprehensive and accurate representation of the domain available in Pfam version 35.0, making it the best choice for the identification of the gene family. To ensure accurate identification and comprehensive coverage of functional DUF789 proteins, HMMER-based detection was followed by rigorous cross-validation with SMART, Pfam re-verification and Conserved Domain Database (CDD) analyses. This integrative approach confirms that all detected candidates possess the canonical DUF789 domain and minimizes the risk of false positives or partial matches. The protein domain sequences for GhDUF789 candidates were extracted from the proteomes of the four cotton species using BLASTP in conjunction with HMMER version 3.0. An E-value threshold of 1e−20 was applied to ensure the specificity of candidate identification. For further validation, the putative DUF789 protein sequences were cross-verified by submission to the Pfam and SMART databases (http://smart.embl-heidelberg.de/) [33], and a Conserved Domain Database (CDD) analysis was performed via NCBI [34] to confirm the presence of the conserved DUF789 domain.

sec.title: Physicochemical characterization and subcellular localization prediction
sec.p: The isoelectric points, amino acid lengths, and molecular weights of DUF789 proteins were assessed through physicochemical characterization using the ExPASy ProtParam tool (http://us.expasy.org/tools/protparam.html) [35]. Furthermore, subcellular localization of DUF789 family members was predicted using the WoLF PSORT platform, available online at https://wolfpsort.hgc.jp/ [36].

sec.title: Evolutionary analysis of DUF789 in cotton
sec.p: To investigate the evolutionary relationships of DUF789 proteins between Arabidopsis thaliana and four cotton species (G. raimondii, G. barbadense, G. hirsutum, and G. arboreum), multiple sequence alignment of DUF789 protein sequences from all five species was performed using ClustalW. A phylogenetic tree was constructed in MEGA 11 using the Maximum Likelihood (ML) method [35], with 1,000 bootstrap replicates performed to assess the statistical robustness of the inferred clades. Bootstrap values of 70% or higher were considered to indicate strong branch support. All other parameters were set to default. The resulting tree was visualized using the Interactive Tree of Life (iTOL) platform (https://itol.embl.de/).

sec.title: Chromosomal distribution, synteny analysis, gene duplication, and Ka/Ks ratio Estimation
sec.p: The chromosomal positions of the DUF789 genes in the genomes of the analysed cotton species were determined using gene annotation data from the CottonMD database (https://yanglab.hzau.edu.cn/CottonMD/download.1). Subsequent chromosomal mapping was performed using the MG2C tool (version 2.1) [37]. The MCScanX module integrated into the TBtools software suite was used to analyses syntenic relationships and gene duplication events. Visualizations of collinearity were created using the Basic CIRCOS function in TBtools (version 1.108) [38]. The rates of synonymous (Ks) and non-synonymous (Ka) substitutions were also calculated using TBtools (v1.108), and the resulting Ka/Ks ratios were used to infer the selection pressure acting on gene pairs. A Ka/Ks ratio < 1 was indicative of purifying selection, a ratio > 1 indicates adaptive (positive) selection and a ratio of 1 indicates neutral evolution.

sec.title: Identification of conserved motifs, protein domains, and gene structure organization
sec.p: To investigate conserved sequence motifs and domain architecture within GhDUF789 proteins, the Multiple Expectation Maximization for Motif Elicitation (MEME) suite (http://meme-suite.org) was utilized under default settings, specifying a maximum of 10 motifs and permitting motif widths ranging from 6 to 50 amino acids. The resulting motifs were manually evaluated for their degree of conservation across family members and their potential functional implications. In addition, the protein sequences of GhDUF789 genes were subjected to domain annotation using the Conserved Domain Database (CDD) (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/cdd/wrpsb.cgi), applying an E-value cut-off of 1e−5 to ensure robust and statistically significant domain identification.

Moreover, TBtools software (v1.108; [38]) was used to generate gene structure diagrams illustrating the exon–intron organization of GhDUF789 genes. Gene annotation files in GFF3 format were obtained from the CottonMD database, and exon–intron structures were visualized using the “Gene Structure View” function in TBtools, with exon lengths, intron sizes, and intron phases preserved to accurately denote genomic architecture.

sec.title: Cis-Acting element analysis in GhDUF789 promoters
sec.p: To explore putative cis-regulatory elements involved in transcriptional regulation of GhDUF789 genes, 2,000 base pairs of upstream promoter regions with respect to the initiation site of translation were extracted from the genome of Gossypium hirsutum based on gene annotation information from the CottonMD database (https://yanglab.hzau.edu.cn/CottonMD/). The prediction of cis-acting regulatory elements within these promoter regions was conducted using the PlantCARE database (https://bioinformatics.psb.ugent.be/webtools/plantcare/html/), which identifies known cis-elements associated with hormonal regulation, stress responses, and developmental processes. The identified cis-elements were classified based on their functional relevance, including those responsive to abscisic acid (ABA), methyl jasmonate (MeJA), gibberellin (GA), salicylic acid (SA), and various light-responsive elements. To enable comparative analysis among family members, the distribution and abundance of cis-elements across GhDUF789 promoters were visualized using TBtools software (v1.108). This visualization was integrated with the phylogenetic tree of the DUF789 gene family, allowing for the identification of potential correlations between regulatory element complexity and evolutionary divergence within the gene family.

sec.title: Prediction of protein–protein interactions (PPIs)
sec.p: To investigate possible functional relationships between GhDUF789 proteins, protein–protein interaction (PPI) networks were predicted using the STRING database version 12.0 [39]. The full-length amino acid sequences of GhDUF789 family members were entered into the STRING web interface (https://string-db.org/), using the setting for the organism G. hirsutum. The analysis was performed using the default parameters, with a threshold for mean confidence in the interaction of 0.4. Both known and predicted interactions were considered, including those based on experimental evidence, curated databases, gene neighborhood, gene fusion, co-expression, co-occurrence and homology (interolog-based prediction). The resulting interaction network was visualized to assess within-family and between-family associations, and the strength of the interaction was inferred based on the confidence values for the edges. Functional partners were also identified and annotated using UniProt and STRING enrichment tools.

sec.title: Prediction of putative MiRNAs targeting GhDUF789 genes and enrichment analyses
sec.p: To identify potential microRNAs (miRNAs) regulating the GhDUF789 gene family, mature cotton miRNA sequences reported in previous studies were obtained [40]. The coding sequences (CDS) of all identified GhDUF789 genes were entered into the psRNATarget server (https://www.zhaolab.org/psRNATarget/) using default prediction parameters. Predicted miRNA–gene interactions were visualized using Cytoscape (version 3.10.1; https://cytoscape.org/download.html).

Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis of GhDUF789 genes was performed using the AgriGO v2 platform, while the associated metabolic and signaling pathways were investigated by Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) analysis via the KEGG database. These functional annotations facilitated the identification of biological processes and molecular pathways potentially controlled by miRNA-mediated regulation of GhDUF789 gene expression.

sec.title: RNA extraction and quantitative Real-Time PCR (qRT-PCR) validation of GhDUF789 gene expression during fibre development
sec.p: Transcriptome datasets were retrieved from the Cotton Omics Database (http://cotton.zju.edu.cn/) to assess GhDUF789 gene expression across key stages of cotton fibre development (0, 5, 10, 15, and 20 days post-anthesis [DPA]). FPKM (Fragments Per Kilobase of transcript per Million mapped reads) values were used to create a heatmap with TBtools (v1.108), illustrating spatiotemporal expression patterns, particularly during fibre elongation and the biosynthesis of secondary wall.

To confirm the transcriptomic results, total RNA was extracted from developing cotton boll fiber tissue taken at a specific time point after anthesis (DPA). The tissue samples were rapidly frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at − 80 °C until further processing. RNA isolation was performed using the hot borate protocol as described by Hamid et al. [41]. First-strand synthesis of complementary DNA (cDNA) was carried out using the PrimeScript™ RT Reagent Kit with gDNA Eraser (TaKaRa, Japan) to avoid contamination with genomic DNA. Quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) was done in the Eco Real-Time PCR System (Illumina, USA) with SYBR® Premix Ex Taq™ (TaKaRa, Japan) according to the methodology described in Hamid et al. [42]. Relative transcript abundance was calculated using the 2−ΔΔCT method (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001) using GhEF1α as an endogenous control. Each gene expression assay comprised three biological replicates, each analyzed in triplicate (technical replicates). Gene-specific primers were designed using Primer Premier 5.0, with sequences provided in Table S1. Expression variation among developmental stages was statistically assessed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), and differences were considered significant at p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
Characterization and molecular analysis of cotton DUF789 proteins
sec.p: In the present study, members of the DUF789 gene family were systematically identified in four Gossypium species: G. hirsutum, G. barbadense, G. arboreum and G. raimondii. The identification was based on the sequence homology to 11 DUF789 proteins of A. thaliana from the TAIR database. A total of 91 DUF789 genes were annotated, which are distributed among the individual species as follows: G. hirsutum (24), G. barbadense (31), G. arboreum (18), and G. raimondii (18). It is noteworthy that the number of DUF789 genes in the allopolyploid species G. hirsutum and G. barbadense does not correspond to the additive total number of their ancestral diploid genomes (G. arboreum and G. raimondii), which together encode 36 DUF789 genes. This suggests the occurrence of post-polyploidization gene loss or differential gene retention. Such patterns are frequently observed in polyploid genomes, where selective gene loss, genome fractionation, and sub functionalization contribute to gene family contraction or expansion. The disparity between the two tetraploids further implies lineage-specific evolutionary trajectories, with G. barbadense retaining more duplicates than G. hirsutum, possibly due to relaxed purifying selection or functional divergence.

To investigate the molecular properties of the DUF789 proteins, we analyzed their physicochemical properties, including protein length, molecular weight (MW), theoretical pI, GRAVY score, aliphatic index and instability index (Table S2). Despite the conservation of the DUF789 domain, significant differences were observed between species for these parameters. In G. hirsutum, the DUF789 proteins were between 307 and 429 amino acids in length and had a molecular weight between 35.34 and 48.29 kDa. The theoretical pI values varied between 4.54 and 7.67, indicating a wide range of predicted net charges under physiological conditions. GRAVY values were uniformly negative (–0.677 to − 0.397), confirming the hydrophilic nature of GhDUF789 proteins. The aliphatic index ranged from 61.74 to 76.66, indicating moderate thermostability, while the instability index values ranged from 41.84 to 81.52, reflecting the variability of the predicted in vivo stability (Figure S1). These physicochemical properties can have direct effects on subcellular localization, molecular interactions and protein function under different cellular conditions [43]. For example, proteins with lower pI values (acidic range) are more likely to function in environments such as the cytoplasm or acidic organelles, whereas proteins with higher or near-neutral pI values are more likely to have nuclear or plastid-associated activities, supporting a possible role in transcriptional regulation or metabolic coordination [6, 44]. In particular, proteins such as GbDUF789-A15 (> 100 kDa) are likely to be domain fusion variants that may have acquired novel functions related to vesicle trafficking, stress response or transcriptional regulation, which is further supported by the GO enrichment and protein interaction data (Sections "Prediction of interactions between proteins (PPIs), secondary structure, and 3D structure of members of the GhDUF789 family of cotton", "Interaction between GhDUF789 genes and MiRNAs in upland cotton" and "GO enrichment analysis of members of the GhDUF789 family"). The size differences also suggest different interaction capacities, with larger DUF789 proteins possibly acting as scaffold-like elements in multiprotein complexes. Overall, these results suggest that the observed variability in physicochemical parameters contributes to structural and functional diversification within the DUF789 family, possibly due to sub functionalization or neofunctionalization [6].

A comparable pattern was observed in G. barbadense, where DUF789 proteins ranged from 289 to 1203 amino acids in length and exhibited molecular weights between 33.16 and 132.82 kDa. The pI values extended from 4.61 to 8.78, with several proteins such as GbDUF789-A15 and GbDUF789-D20 displaying both high molecular weights (> 100 kDa) and basic PI values (> 7.9), which may indicate functional divergence or domain fusion events absent in the diploid progenitors. In contrast, the diploid species G. arboreum and G. raimondii harbored shorter DUF789 proteins, ranging from 298 to 392 amino acids, with molecular weights between approximately 33 and 44.5 kDa. Their PI values spanned 4.49 to 6.52, and GRAVY scores remained negative, confirming their hydrophilic nature. The aliphatic and instability indices were broadly comparable to the tetraploids, indicating a conserved structural framework across ploidy levels. Subcellular localization of the identified DUF789 proteins was predicted using the CELLO computational tool. As illustrated in Figure S1, the majority of cotton DUF789 proteins were predicted to reside predominantly in the chloroplast and nuclear compartments.

The chromosomal distribution of DUF789 genes was uneven across the four species (Fig. 1). In G. hirsutum, 24 GhDUF789 genes were located on 20 chromosomes, with chromosome A01 harboring the highest number (four genes). Chromosomes A02, A06, A07, D04, D06, D09, and D13 each contained a single gene. A similar pattern was seen in G. barbadense, which consisted of 31 DUF789 genes across 20 chromosomes, again with chromosome A01 hosting four genes. Other chromosomes including A02, A06, A08, D01, and D04 were not as densely populated, each containing only a single gene. In the diploid progenitors, the distribution was more compact. G. arboreum contained 18 DUF789 genes distributed across 11 chromosomes, with the highest concentration (four genes) on A01. Chromosomes A06, A08, and A10 each carried a single gene. In G. raimondii, 18 DUF789 genes were localized to 10 chromosomes, with chromosome D01 hosting three genes, while D03, D04, D09, D10, and D12 each carried a single gene. These patterns suggest that lineage-specific expansion of the DUF789 family occurred in the polyploid species following polyploidization. The observed variation in chromosomal localization and physicochemical properties may reflect processes of neofunctionalisation or subfunctionalisation, potentially driving functional diversification within this gene family across different cotton lineages.

caption.p: Chromosomal locations and gene duplication events of DUF789 genes. The corresponding chromosome numbers are given to the left of each bar. GhDUF789 gene pairs resulting from segmental and tandem duplications are connected by lines. Distribution of GhDUF789 genes on chromosomes of G. hirsutum (A), G. barbadense (B), G. arboreum (C), G. raimondii (D)

sec.title: Evolutionary relationships and phylogenetic classification of DUF789 genes in Gossypium
sec.p: To investigate the evolutionary divergence of the DUF789 gene family in Gossypium hirsutum, the ClustalW algorithm within the MEGA 11 software suite was employed to carry out a multiple sequence alignment of 24 GhDUF789 protein sequences. Subsequently, an unrooted phylogenetic tree was generated using the neighbor-joining (NJ) method. This phylogenetic analysis divided the GhDUF789 proteins into three distinct clades, as shown in Fig. 2A. The largest subfamily, DUF789-I, comprises 10 GhDUF789 genes, followed by DUF789-III with 8 genes and DUF789-II with 6 genes. Clade topology was supported by moderate to high bootstrap values (71–97%), indicating robust statistical confidence in the inferred relationships. The clustering of genes within each subfamily indicates potential functional conservation among members. Notably, several gene pairs derived from homoeologous A and D subgenomes were clustered together, indicating a robust evolutionary conservation after the polyploidization event.

caption.p: (A) The phylogenetic analysis of GhDUF789 genes. (B) The phylogenetic analysis of DUF789 genes among Arabidopsis and four cotton species. The phylogenetic tree was constructed using the program MEGA11.0. (The maximum-likelihood) algorithm, bootstrap value = 1000). The prefixes Ga, Gr, Gh and Gb represent G. arboretum, G. raimondii, G. hirsutum and G. barbadense, respectively. Bootstrap values are indicated by triangular node symbols of varying sizes, with larger triangles corresponding to higher bootstrap support values (closer to 1.0), signifying greater confidence in the branching patterns

sec.p: To enlarge the evolutionary context, a comprehensive phylogenetic analysis was carried out, which included DUF789 protein sequences from four Gossypium species in addition to the A. thaliana sequences. A total of 102 protein sequences were analyzed, including 24 from G. hirsutum, 31 from G. barbadense, 18 each from G. arboreum and G. raimondii and 11 from A. thaliana. As shown in Fig. 2B, these sequences were categorised into five different subclades: DUF789-I, DUF789-II, DUF789-III, DUF789-V, and DUF789-VI. Of these, DUF789-VI was the largest group with 29 members, while DUF789-II was the smallest with only 9 members. The remaining clades DUF789-I, DUF789-III and DUF789-V comprised 27, 11 and 26 genes, respectively. The branching pattern of these clades was consistently supported by bootstrap values ≥ 70%, affirming the statistical robustness of the phylogenetic classification.

The extensive phylogenetic distribution of DUF789 proteins across nearly all branches of the tree highlights their strong evolutionary conservation within dicotyledonous lineages. The detection of orthologous genes in both tetraploid species (G. barbadense and G. hirsutum) and their diploid progenitors (G. raimondii and G. arboreum) validates the hypothesis that the tetraploid cotton species originated via ancient allopolyploidisation events. In addition, the recurrent pairing of GhDUF789 and GbDUF789 genes underscores their shared tetraploid origin and indicates the retention of homologous gene relationships following polyploidization.

sec.title: Evolutionary origins and divergence of GhDUF789 gene members
sec.p: To elucidate the evolutionary development of the GhDUF789 gene family in Gossypium hirsutum, an interspecific synteny analysis was performed using the Python implementation of MCScan within the JCVI toolkit. Comparative genomic analyses were conducted with the genomes of G. raimondii, G. arboreum, G. barbadense and A. thaliana. As shown in Supplementary Table 3, the analysis identified twelve syntenic gene pairs between GhDUF789 and GaDUF789, twenty-four between GhDUF789 and GbDUF789, twelve between GhDUF789 and GrDUF789, and seven between GhDUF789 and AtDUF789 (Fig. 3A). The significantly larger number of DUF789 genes in the tetraploid species G. barbadense and G. hirsutum compared to A. thaliana indicates that a substantial expansion of the gene family likely occurred during the diversification of the Gossypium lineage.

caption.p: Evolutionary analysis of the GhDUF789. (A) Collinearity analysis of the genomes of G. arboretum, G. raimondii, G. hirsutum G. barbadense and A. thaliana. Grey lines represent syntenic sequences, and the highlighted blue lines indicated syntenic gene pairs of GhDUF789. (B) Collinearity analysis of the genomes of G. arboretum, G. raimondii, and G. hirsutum. (C) Analysis of segmental and tandem duplication of the GhDUF789. The values indicated identity (%). (D) Collinearity analysis of G. hirsutum DUF789 genes, A01 to A13 represent chromosomes of the A subgenome, while D01 to D13 represent chromosomes of the D subgenome

sec.p: The analysis also revealed a high degree of collinearity between the GhDUF789 genes in G. hirsutum and the GbDUF789 genes in G. barbadense, consistent with their common tetraploid origin and identical chromosomal constitution (2n = 4x = 52) (Table S3a). To clarify the evolutionary contributions of the diploid ancestors, eleven GhDUF789 genes were assigned to the origin of G. arboreum after exclusion of syntenic Ga–Gh pairs that showed collinearity with the D subgenome of G. hirsutum. Conversely, another eleven GhDUF789 genes were attributed to G. raimondii by excluding those that showed collinearity with the A subgenome (Fig. 3B). The theory that the two diploid ancestors contributed almost equally to the GhDUF789 gene set is supported by these findings. The lower number of DUF789 genes in G. raimondii and G. arboreum compared to G. hirsutum also suggests that additional GhDUF789 members likely arose after polyploidization.

We performed a detailed analysis of gene duplication to quantify the relative contributions of tandem and segmental duplications in the four species. In G. hirsutum, 8 of 24 genes (33.3%) arose by tandem duplication, while 16 genes (66.7%) arose by segmental or whole-genome duplication. In G. barbadense, the duplication classification revealed a striking dominance of segmental duplication, with all 31 DUF789 genes (100%) assigned to the segmental/WGD category. In G. raimondii, 10 of 18 genes (55.6%) were segmental, 4 were dispersed (22.2%) and 3 were singular (16.7%), while only 1 tandem duplication was observed (5.6%). In G. arboreum, 14 of 18 genes (77.8%) were segmental, 1 was dispersed, 2 were singular and none arose by tandem duplication. This comparative analysis shows that segmental duplication is the predominant mechanism for expansion of the DUF789 gene family in all four Gossypium species, with tandem duplications occurring only in G. hirsutum (Table S3b). Specifically, in G. hirsutum, events of segmental duplication, such as the one from GhDUF789D-15 to GhDUF789D-16 illustrate the influence of polyploidization. Tandem duplications involving GhDUF789A-1, A-3, and A-7 led to the formation of GhDUF789A-2, A-4, and A-8, respectively (Fig. 3C). The absence of tandem duplicates in other cotton species further underscores the lineage-specific expansion in G. hirsutum, potentially driven by selective pressures or genome dynamics unique to this lineage.

To assess the genomic distribution and syntenic relationships between the A and D subgenomes of G. hirsutum, we performed intraspecific collinearity analysis (Fig. 3D). The resulting circular diagram displays robust syntenic connections between pairs of homologous chromosomes such as A05–D05, A06–D06 and A07–D07, indicating conserved ancestral blocks that were maintained after allopolyploidization. The high level of collinearity that has been preserved between the subgenomes is demonstrated by these connections, which are illustrated by green curves. In contrast, a subset of syntenic connections highlighted in red indicates possible gene rearrangements, translocations or non-collinear duplications, suggesting an ongoing restructuring of the genome since the formation of the tetraploid. This intragenomic synteny not only supports the hypothesis of a common origin of subgenomes A and D, but also suggests that internal duplications and chromosomal dynamics have contributed to the expansion and divergence of the GhDUF789 gene family.

In addition, the selection pressure on DUF789 gene pairs was assessed by calculating the ratio of non-synonymous (Ka) to synonymous (Ks) substitution rates (Ka/Ks). Among the GhDUF789–GbDUF789 paralogues, twenty-one showed Ka/Ks ratios below 1, indicating purifying selection, while three showed ratios above 1, indicating positive selection (Table S4). In the comparative analysis between GhDUF789 and GaDUF789, seven gene pairs were subject to purifying selection, while five showed evidence of positive selection. Similarly, ten GhDUF789–GrDUF789 gene pairs showed Ka/Ks values consistent with purifying selection, and two were identified under positive selection. The preponderance of Ka/Ks values below one in these comparisons emphasizes the influence of strong purifying selection, suggesting the evolutionary conservation of essential functional roles within the GhDUF789 gene family throughout Gossypium diversification.

sec.title: Exploring the evolutionary relationships, conserved motifs, protein domains, and gene structures of GhDUF789 family members in G. hirsutum
sec.p: To clarify the evolutionary and structural features of the GhDUF789 gene family in upland cotton, we performed an integrated analysis of phylogeny, gene structures, conserved domains, motifs, and conservation at the sequence level (Fig. 4A–E). The phylogenetic tree (Fig. 4A) grouped the GhDUF789 proteins into three distinct clades (I–III), indicating functional diversification during evolution. Members within the same clade showed strong sequence similarity, providing a basis for comparative structural and functional inference. Domain architecture analysis (Fig. 4B) confirmed that all GhDUF789 proteins contain the canonical DUF789 domain that defines this family. No additional domains were detected, suggesting that the functional diversity of these proteins may result primarily from other regulatory features such as gene structure or motif composition. Gene structure analysis (Fig. 4C) revealed considerable differences in the exon–intron organization of the GhDUF789 genes. The number of exons ranged from three to nine, indicating different structural architectures. This variation can be attributed to evolutionary events such as exon or intron gain and loss, which are known to drive gene family expansion and possible neofunctionalization. Remarkably, genes within the same phylogenetic group generally had similar exon–intron configurations, supporting the phylogenetic classification and indicating evolutionary conservation at the structural level. Analysis of the conserved motifs (Fig. 4D) identified ten distinct motifs distributed across the GhDUF789 proteins. Motifs 1, 3 and 7 were consistently present, suggesting that they play an essential role in maintaining the structural integrity or basic function of the DUF789 proteins. Conversely, the presence of clade-specific motifs - e.g. motifs 5 and 9 in clade II may indicate specialized regulatory or functional roles in the subgroups, possibly reflecting underfunctionalization after gene duplication. Sequence conservation analysis using sequence logos (Fig. 4E) revealed several highly conserved amino acid residues within the DUF789 domain. These residues are likely critical for maintaining structural stability or mediating protein interactions, particularly in response to developmental or environmental stimuli. The differences in residue conservation between clades may reflect adaptive divergence under different selective pressures. Overall, this comprehensive analysis of phylogeny, domain structure, exon–intron organization, motif distribution and sequence conservation highlights both the conserved core architecture and clade-specific specializations of the GhDUF789 gene family. These results provide a valuable framework for future functional characterization of GhDUF789 genes in the context of cotton development and adaptation to stress.

caption.p: Gene Structure, Conserved Motifs, Domains, and Chromosomal Localization of the GhDUF789 Gene Family in upland cotton. (A) Phylogenetic tree of GhDUF789genes depicting their evolutionary relationships. Different colors indicate distinct clades. (B) Domain architecture of GhDUF789proteins, highlighting conserved functional domains with different colors. (C) Gene structure analysis displaying exon-intron organization of GhDUF789genes. Yellow boxes represent exons, black lines represent introns. (D) Conserved motif distribution among GhBAG proteins. Identified motifs are color-coded. (E) Sequence logo representation illustrating conserved amino acid residues in GhBAG proteins

sec.title: Cis-Acting regulatory element analysis of GhDUF789 genes
sec.p: To understand the GhDUF789 gene transcriptional regulation, we analyzed the cis-acting regulatory elements within the 2 kb upstream promoter regions using the PlantCARE database (Fig. 5A&B). A total of 1,138 cis-elements were detected and categorised into four main functional categories: light-dependent (288; 25.3%), stress-dependent (489; 43.0%), hormone-dependent (239; 21.0%) and development-related elements (122; 10.7%). Among the 62 unique cis-element types identified, the most abundant elements in all the categories were MBS (137; MYB binding site for dryness), Box 4 (102; light-dependent), ERE (59; ethylene-dependent), ABRE (42; ABA-dependent), STRE (43; stress-dependent), GT1 motif (43; light-dependent) and G-box (50; light/hormone signaling-dependent).

caption.p: (A) Analysis of cis-regulatory elements on GhDUF789 genes. Heatmap showing the distribution of cis-acting elements in the 2 kb promoter regions of GhDUF789 genes. Elements are categorized into cell cycle/development, hormone-, light-, and stress-responsive groups, with a phylogenetic tree on the left

sec.p: In the light-responsive group (288 elements in total), box 4 was predominant (102), followed by G-box (50), GT1-motif (43), GATA-motif (19), AE-box (18) and circadian-related elements (9). The promoters of GhDUF789D-24, GhDUF789D-20 and GhDUF789A-8 showed the highest density of these motifs, indicating a potential role in photomorphogenesis, diurnal rhythm and chloroplast gene expression. The stress-responsive category (489 elements) was the most functionally diverse. MBS motifs (137) were the most abundant, followed by ARE (anaerobic induction; 53), STRE (general stress response; 43), LTR (low temperature response; 26) and W-box (22; WRKY TF binding). Other motifs associated with biotic stress were TC-rich repeats (16), the WUN motif (12) and WRE3 (7). Genes such as GhDUF789D-13, GhDUF789D-18 and GhDUF789D-23 showed extensive arrangements of these elements, suggesting a regulatory role under abiotic and biotic stress. The hormone-responsive group (239 elements) included motifs for several hormone pathways. ERE (59) was the most abundant, followed by ABRE (42), ABRE3a (18) and ABRE4 (13), indicating strong ABA- and ethylene-related reactivity. Jasmonic acid-related TGACG and CGTCA motifs were also frequent (32 in total), as were gibberellin-related P-box, GARE and TATC-box elements (30 in total). Auxin-related TGA boxes, TGA elements and AuxRR cores were identified in 12 cases and the salicylic acid-responsive TCA element was found in 7 cases. In particular, GhDUF789A-10, GhDUF789A-12 and GhDUF789D-21 showed a high density of ABA- and ethylene-associated motifs.

Development-related elements (122) were the least represented, but showed different regulatory patterns. The AAGAA motif (45) was the most abundant, followed by the O2 site (13), the CAT box (7), the GA motif (7) and other elements such as the gap box and the F box (5 each). These motifs are involved in seed development, meristem activity and cellular differentiation. The GhDUF789D-17, GhDUF789A-5 and GhDUF789D-15 promoters were particularly enriched in these elements, indicating stage-specific developmental regulation. Overall, the seven most abundant cis-elements were MBS (137), Box 4 (102), ERE (59), ABRE (42), STRE (43), GT1 motif (43) and G-box (50), suggesting that GhDUF789 gene regulation is strongly influenced by drought, light signaling, ABA and ethylene signaling pathways and general stress factors. The combinatorial presence of these elements in individual promoters suggests a highly integrated transcriptional regulatory system that responds to multiple environmental and hormonal signals. These results validate the hypothesis that GhDUF789 genes are versatile regulators involved in light-dependent development, abiotic stress adaptation and hormone-mediated signal transduction, with implications for fibre development and stress resistance in cotton.

sec.title: Prediction of interactions between proteins (PPIs), secondary structure, and 3D structure of members of the GhDUF789 family of cotton
sec.p: The investigation of protein–protein interactions (PPIs) offers crucial insights into the potential functions of previously uncharacterized proteins [45]. To explain the potential functional roles of GhDUF789 proteins in upland cotton (G. hirsutum), we predicted their PPIs using STRING analysis (Fig. 6A). Our analysis demonstrated that members of the GhDUF789 family interact strongly with each other, suggesting possible functional redundancy or cooperative activities within the family (Table S5). GhDUF789D-24 and GhDUF789D-22 exhibited particularly strong associations.

caption.p: Protein-protein interaction of GhDUF789 proteins based on known Arabidopsis protein orthologous. (A) The network was constructed using the online STRING software. The proteins were displayed at network nodes with 3D structure of the proteins in nodes, and the line colors indicate different data sources. (B) Predicted 3D models of GhDUF789 proteins. 3D models were constructed using the online Phyre2 server with default mode. (C) Phylogenetic analysis of GhDUF789 proteins. Each colour line represents a different subfamily of the phylogeny, highlighting the evolutionary relationships among the GhDUF789 proteins

sec.p: In addition to intra-family interactions, GhDUF789 proteins were also predicted to interact with several other proteins, including Q7XJK7_ARATH and B3H5S0_ARATH, which are annotated as hypothetical or conserved domain-containing proteins, thereby highlighting the still largely uncharacterized nature of this protein family. Significant interactions were further observed with AREP1, a protein involved in mitochondrial regulation, and with MPL12.4 and MPL12.5, components of the large mitochondrial ribosomal subunit. These interactions suggest that GhDUF789 proteins may be implicated in mitochondrial processes such as energy metabolism and protein biosynthesis. Other predicted interactors, including F10C21.3, F10B6.6, F12B17_240, and F10C12.140, represent additional conserved or hypothetical proteins that could potentially expand the functional repertoire of GhDUF789 proteins. The width of the edges shown in Fig. 6A reflects the strength of the predicted interactions, with thicker edges indicating higher confidence values (Fig. 6B illustrates the interaction types and evidence sources).

The structural composition of GhDUF789 proteins were further elucidated via secondary structure analysis. The elements were categorised into alpha helices, beta turns, extended strands, and random coils (Table S6). Alpha helices constituted the predominant ordered structural component, although their proportion was relatively modest, ranging from 19.35% (GhDUF789A-10) to 25.95% (GhDUF789A-12 and GhDUF789D-24). Extended strands contributed between 6.11% (GhDUF789A-6) and 11.40% (GhDUF789D-17), demonstrating the presence of limited beta-sheet structures. Notably, beta turns were absent in all GhDUF789 proteins, suggesting a preference for simpler or more flexible loop regions rather than tightly folded turns. Random coils dominated the secondary structure, with proportions ranging from 63.92% (GhDUF789A-12) to 72.73% (GhDUF789A-7), reflecting a high degree of intrinsic disorder and structural flexibility within this protein family.

The 3D structures and models for all 24 GhDUF789 proteins were predicted using the Phyre2 online server. A total of eight different templates were used to model the entire protein set, with the most commonly used templates being A0A7J8RK08.1.A and A0A6P4PVQ8.1.A (Table S6). Each model was created using Phyre2’s intensive mode, which uses advanced homology-based fold detection [46]. Phyre2 confidence values represent the estimated probability that the predicted fold is correct, with values above 80% generally considered high confidence in comparative modelling pipelines [46, 47]. In our analysis, Phyre2 confidence values ranged from 81 to 92%, with the majority of residuals in each model modelled at > 90% confidence. These values reflect a high degree of reliability and robustness in the structural predictions. In addition, the sequence identity between the GhDUF789 proteins and their structural templates ranged from 28 to 47%, which is within the accepted range for fold recognition-based modelling of plant proteins [48]. Most models also showed an alignment coverage of more than 80%, ensuring structural completeness and accuracy. The 3D modelling results showed that the GhDUF789 proteins have a high degree of structural similarity, suggesting a common evolutionary origin (Fig. 6C). The DUF789 domain primarily adopted a mixed alpha-helical and coiled conformation, consistent with its role in flexible protein–protein interactions. Most GhDUF789 proteins were modelled using templates containing DUF789 domains, with C-score values ranging from 0.81 to 0.92. C-scores in this range correspond to high-confidence models suitable for functional interpretation in structural plant genomics [49]. These models showed predominantly random coil regions interspersed with ordered helices, consistent with the predictions of secondary structure. The strong agreement between secondary and tertiary structure data highlights the internal consistency and reliability of our modelling approach. Taken together, these combined metrics Phyre2 confidence scores, sequence identity, alignment coverage, C-scores and structural consistency support the high reliability of the predicted GhDUF789 protein models and confirm their utility for downstream functional inference and evolutionary comparisons.

sec.title: Interaction between GhDUF789 genes and MiRNAs in upland cotton
sec.p: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are important post-transcriptional regulators that modulate gene expression through mRNA cleavage or translational inhibition. To investigate the regulatory landscape between GhDUF789 genes and miRNAs in upland cotton (G. hirsutum), a genome-wide in silico analysis was performed to predict potential miRNA–target interactions.

A total of 17 high-probability interactions were identified involving nine GhDUF789 genes and two major miRNA families, miR414 and miR396 (Table S7). These results indicate a moderately complex yet specific regulatory network. Notably, members of the ghr-miR414 family (including miR414a–f) were consistently predicted to be targets of GhDUF789A−4 and GhDUF789D−16 with expected values ≤ 4.0 and cleavage-based inhibition, indicating a conserved regulatory mechanism. The recurrence of these interactions across multiple miR414 isoforms underscores functional redundancy and robustness in the post-transcriptional control of these genes, potentially under developmental or stress-related conditions.

In addition to miR414, ghr-miR396a was predicted to regulate six GhDUF789 genes A-2, A-5, A-10, D-14, D-17, and D-22, exhibiting both cleavage and translational repression. Specifically, GhDUF789A−5 and GhDUF789D−17 were predicted to undergo translational inhibition, highlighting the regulatory versatility of miR396a. Given miR396’s established role in growth modulation and stress adaptation in cotton and other species, these interactions likely contribute to the fine-tuning of GhDUF789 gene expression in diverse physiological contexts (Fig. 7).

caption.p: Schematic representation of GhDUF789 genes targeted by ghr-miRNAs in upland cotton. Predicted miRNA target sites on GhDUF789 genes are shown alongside exon–intron structures. Blue boxes indicate exons; black lines represent introns. Red vertical bars mark predicted miRNA binding sites. The aligned sequences of each miRNA and its corresponding target site are displayed, with vertical lines representing complementary base pairing. Multiple members of the ghr-miR414 and ghr-miR396 families were predicted to target GhDUF789 genes, primarily through cleavage or translation inhibition mechanisms

sec.p: Furthermore, a lineage-specific interaction was predicted between ghr-miR414d and GhDUF789D−19, distinct from the conserved targets shared by other miR414 isoforms. This unique targeting event may reflect a species- or context-specific regulatory adaptation, meriting further experimental validation. Collectively, these findings reveal the nuanced, miRNA-mediated regulation of GhDUF789 genes, particularly by conserved miRNAs associated with developmental and stress-responsive pathways. The predominance of cleavage-based interactions suggests selective evolutionary pressure to maintain precise gene dosage and spatiotemporal expression. Future experimental validation using degradome sequencing, dual-luciferase assays, and stress-responsive expression profiling will be crucial to confirm these interactions and elucidate their biological relevance. Such insights could ultimately inform miRNA-guided genetic strategies for enhancing cotton stress resilience.

sec.title: GO enrichment analysis of members of the GhDUF789 family
sec.p: To clarify the potential biological functions of the GhDUF789 gene family in G. hirsutum, we performed a Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis and categorised the genes into three main areas: biological process (BP), molecular function (MF) and cellular component (CC) (Fig. 8; Table S8). In the biological process (BP) category, GhDUF789 genes were significantly enriched in terms related to clathrin-mediated vesicle transport, including clathrin coat assembly (GO:0048268), clathrin-dependent endocytosis (GO:0072583), and detachment of vesicles from the membrane (GO:0006900). These processes are critical for membrane dynamics, internalization of receptors and regulation of intracellular transport, all of which are important during cellular differentiation, stress signaling and developmental transitions.

caption.p: Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analyses of GhDUF789 genes

sec.p: Significant enrichment of terms related to lipid binding and vesicle-associated interactions, including 1-phosphatidylinositol binding (GO:0005545), phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate binding (GO:0005546) and SNARE binding (GO:0000149), was observed within the molecular functional domain (MF). The presence of clathrin heavy chain binding (GO:0032050) highlights the role of GhDUF789 proteins in clathrin-mediated membrane trafficking, vesicle docking and fusion events, possibly related to signaling and cargo transport.

In the Cellular Components (CC) category, the most enriched terms were clathrin-coated pit (GO:0005905) and clathrin-coated vesicle (GO:0030136), indicating the likely subcellular localization of GhDUF789 proteins within membrane trafficking hubs involved in endocytosis and vesicle trafficking. Overall, the GO enrichment profile of GhDUF789 genes emphasizes a conserved role in clathrin-dependent regulation of the endomembrane system. The strong enrichment for lipid-binding GO terms related to vesicle fusion and transport and the localization in clathrin-coated structures suggests that these genes may be involved in auxin and abscisic acid signaling, receptor turnover and intracellular transport during fiber development and adaptation to abiotic stress. These results suggest that the GhDUF789 gene family contributes to cellular plasticity and stress-dependent developmental remodeling in G. hirsutum.

sec.title: Expression of GhDUF789 genes in various tissues and during fiber development
sec.p: To investigate the tissue-specific expression patterns of GhDUF789 genes, we analyzed publicly available transcriptome data (FPKM values) in a range of tissues, including cotyledon, calyx, leaf, petal, pistil, root, stamen, stem, torus, seed coat, seed and fibers at different developmental stages of TM-1 (Fig. 9). The majority of GhDUF789 genes exhibited different expression profiles in the different tissues, with several genes showing tissue-specific patterns. For example, GhDUF789A−6 showed high expression in the cotyledon, calycle, leaf, root, stamen, stem and torus, suggesting an extensive role in early developmental processes. In contrast, GhDUF789A−4 showed significantly increased expression specifically in the petals, suggesting a possible function in flower development.

caption.p: (A) Heat map of GhDUF789 gene expression across diverse tissues and developmental stages in upland cotton (G. hirsutum). Transcript abundance (log₂-based FPKM values) is shown for GhDUF789 genes in cotyledon, calycle, leaf, petal, pistil, root, stamen, stem, ovule, torus, seed, and during multiple fibre developmental stages (5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 days post anthesis [dpa]). Expression levels were hierarchically clustered to visualise tissue-specific and stage-specific expression patterns. (B) qRT-PCR results of GhDUF789A-1 and GhDUF789D-13 at different fiber developmental stages

sec.p: Remarkably, several GhDUF789 genes showed significant expression in fiber tissues at different developmental stages. GhDUF789A−1, GhDUF789A−2, GhDUF789A−3, GhDUF789D-13 GhDUF789A−5, GhDUF789A−8 and to a lesser extent GhDUF789A−7 showed progressively increased expression levels during fiber development, with the highest expression observed at later stages such as 20 DPA and 25 DPA (Fig. 9). GhDUF789A−1, for example, showed a dramatic increase in expression from early fiber stages (5 DPA) to late fiber development (25 DPA), reaching its highest expression level at 25 DPA (68.37 FPKM), indicating a possible involvement in secondary cell wall biosynthesis. Similarly, GhDUF789A−2 and GhDUF789A−3 showed increasing expression patterns that correlated with fiber maturation. In addition, GhDUF789D−13 and GhDUF789A−8 also showed upregulation during fiber elongation and secondary wall formation, suggesting their potential role in determining fiber quality. To validate the transcriptome-based expression profiles, we selected two highly expressed fiber-associated genes GhDUF789A-1 and GhDUF789D-13 for quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) analysis. Samples were collected from developing fibers at five major developmental stages (0, 5, 10, 20 and 25 DPA) in the upland cotton variety Shayan. The qRT-PCR results showed expression trends consistent with the RNA-seq data, with both genes showing progressively increasing expression over the course of fiber development, peaking at 20–25 DPA. Expression levels were normalized using the cotton reference gene GhEF1α to ensure accurate quantification across all samples. These results confirmed the transcriptomic expression patterns and reinforced the hypothesis that GhDUF789A-1 and GhDUF789D-13 are actively involved in fiber elongation and secondary wall biosynthesis.

Although many members of the GhDUF789D subfamily showed relatively low expression in all tissues, specific genes such as GhDUF789D−23 showed moderate expression in floral organs, indicating a possible specialized role. Notably, comparative analysis of cis-regulatory elements and expression data revealed a positive correlation between promoter element complexity and transcriptional activity during fibre development. Genes such as GhDUF789A-1, GhDUF789A-2, GhDUF789A-3, and GhDUF789A-8, all of which were highly expressed at key fibre developmental stages, were enriched in multiple regulatory motifs including ABRE, CAT-box, G-box, and Box 4 belonging to ABA-, development-, and light-responsive classes. These genes contained ≥ 15 total cis-elements each, often with ≥ 3 hormone- and ≥ 5 light-related motifs. In contrast, genes such as GhDUF789D-17, which showed negligible fibre expression, contained fewer than 5 cis-elements and lacked key motifs such as ABRE or G-box. This observation underscores the regulatory importance of promoter architecture, supporting the hypothesis that higher cis-element density especially of hormone- and light-responsive motifs may underlie stronger, stage-specific activation of GhDUF789 genes during fibre elongation and secondary wall deposition. Such findings highlight candidate regulatory regions for future functional validation and genetic engineering.

sec.title: Expression profiling of GhDUF789 genes under abiotic stress
sec.p: To investigate the response of the GhDUF789 gene family in cotton to abiotic stress, a comprehensive expression analysis was performed using transcriptomic datasets from the CottonOmics database (http://cotton.zju.edu.cn/). The GhDUF789 genes showed different stress-specific transcriptional responses to cold, heat, drought and salinity.

Under cold stress (Fig. 10A), GhDUF789A-12, GhDUF789D-13 and GhDUF789A-1 were strongly upregulated, especially during the early (1 h) and middle (6 h) exposure phases. In contrast, several genes, such as GhDUF789A-9 and GhDUF789D-17, remained at a low expression level throughout the treatment period. During heat stress (Fig. 10B), GhDUF789D-13 and GhDUF789D-24 showed significant induction, while GhDUF789D-17 showed minimal expression throughout. Remarkably, the expression of most GhDUF789 genes peaked 6 h after treatment, indicating a temporally regulated transcriptional response. Under drought stress (Fig. 10C), GhDUF789D-20 and GhDUF789D-14 were strongly upregulated, with GhDUF789A-4 and GhDUF789A-1 were significantly induced during the treatment period. In contrast, the expression of GhDUF789D-17 remained persistently low under water deficit conditions. In response to salt stress (Fig. 10D), GhDUF789D-13, GhDUF789A-12 and GhDUF789A-1 were strongly induced, with transcript levels increasing over time.

caption.p: Expression profile of GhDUF789 genes in upland cotton. (A) A heat map showing the expression profile of GhDUF789 genes in different abiotic stress condition of cotton. (B) Relative expressions of GhFH genes. qRT-PCR analysis was performed to observe the relative expression patterns of GhDUF789 genes

sec.p: To explore the regulatory basis of these different expression patterns, we analyzed the promoter regions (2 kb upstream) of the GhDUF789 genes for the presence of stress-related cis-acting elements. Remarkably, many strongly stress-responsive genes contained multiple copies of known abiotic stress-responsive motifs. For example, GhDUF789A-1, which was transcriptionally activated under drought, cold and salt stress, contained abundant ABRE (abscisic acid-responsive) and MBS (MYB-binding site for drought) elements. Similarly, GhDUF789A-12, which responded strongly to cold and salt stress, was enriched in DRE (dehydration-responsive element) and CGTCA-motif (jasmonic acid-responsive) elements. GhDUF789D-18, which is highly drought-induced, contained both MBS and LTR elements (associated with responses to low temperature and desiccation). In contrast, GhDUF789D-17, which showed negligible transcriptional changes under any stress condition, lacked these key regulatory elements. This pattern suggests a potential regulatory correlation between the architecture of the cis-elements and the transcriptional sensitivity of GhDUF789 genes to abiotic stimuli.

To validate the transcriptomic profiling results, the expression patterns of three selected GhDUF789 genes (GhDUF789A-1, GhDUF789A-8 and GhDUF789D-17) were further analyzed by qRT-PCR analysis in two contrasting upland cotton genotypes: a drought-resistant line and a drought-susceptible line, under both control and drought stress conditions (Fig. 10E). Under control conditions, all three genes showed relatively low and comparable basal expression levels in both genotypes (normalized to 1.0). Significant up-regulation was observed after drought, especially in the resistant genotype. GhDUF789A-8 showed an approximately 5.5-fold increase in the resistant line compared to a 2.0-fold increase in the susceptible line. Similarly, GhDUF789A-1 showed an approximately 4.8-fold induction in the resistant genotype, while a 1.5-fold increase was observed in the susceptible genotype. GhDUF789D-17 also showed increased expression, with a 3.2-fold increase in the resistant genotype and a 1.8-fold increase in the susceptible line. The qRT-PCR data support the hypothesis that genes with stress-responsive cis-elements (e.g. ABRE, MBS) are transcriptionally activated under stress conditions. These combined results suggest that cis-regulatory motifs in GhDUF789 promoters are likely to be functionally relevant and may play a predictive role in stress-induced gene expression patterns. This correlation provides a molecular basis for the selection of candidate genes for breeding stress-resistant cotton. Although the RNA-Seq data were obtained from a drought-induced time-course experiment in genotype TM-1 and the qRT-PCR experiments were performed using endpoint comparisons in different drought-tolerant and drought-sensitive genotypes, the direction of expression trends was largely consistent across platforms. In particular, all three genes showed stress-induced upregulation in both data sets. To further assess the degree of agreement, we compared fold-change trends and found strong qualitative agreement between qRT-PCR and RNA-Seq. While exact fold-change values varied as expected due to differences in sampling time points, genotypic background, and measurement sensitivity, the overall agreement in direction and magnitude of expression indicates robust cross-platform validation. No major discrepancies were observed. However, minor differences in the extent of upregulation (e.g. higher fold-change values in qRT-PCR for GhDUF789A-8) may reflect increased transcript stability or genotype-specific regulatory effects not detected in the TM-1 reference dataset. These results support the reliability of the transcriptomic data and confirm the involvement of the selected GhDUF789 genes in the response to drought stress. The correlation between the expression platforms also strengthens the case for these genes as candidates for stress-resistant cotton breeding programs.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Domains of Unknown Function (DUFs) represent a considerable proportion of annotated but poorly characterized proteins in various plant genomes [6, 9]. Despite their ambiguous name, recent studies have increasingly linked DUF-containing proteins to vital biological functions, including metabolism, development and stress responses [50]. Though the DUF789 gene family has been identified in several plant species [27, 51], it remains relatively understudied, particularly in large polyploid plants such as cotton (Gossypium spp.). In this context, the present study provides the first systematic, genome-wide identification, characterization and functional exploration of the cotton DUF789 gene family, offering crucial insights into its evolutionary history and potential role in fibre development and adaptation to abiotic stress.

Out of a total of 91 DUF789 genes, identified in the four cotton species, 24 members were present in G. hirsutum. Notably, G. barbadense retained a higher number of DUF789 genes (31) compared to G. hirsutum, suggesting possible pedigree-specific duplication or retention patterns consistent with the observed stronger retention of stress-related genes in G. barbadense [52]. In G. hirsutum, there was an uneven distribution of the 24 DUF789 genes across ten chromosomes, with a predominant concentration on A06 chromosome, as shown in Table S1. The DUF789 genes were also mapped on ten chromosomes in G. barbadense. In contrast, the DUF789 genes in the diploid progenitors G. arboreum and G. raimondii were distributed on five chromosomes, albeit at different chromosomal locations in the two species. The presence of family members on different chromosomes in different species may reflect the different functional specializations of these genes [53].

Physicochemical characterization revealed that the GhDUF789 proteins are hydrophilic and moderately thermostable, with a wide variation in molecular masses and isoelectric points, consistent with results for DUF789 proteins in Arabidopsis [27]. The predicted nuclear and chloroplastic localization of most GhDUF789 proteins suggests a possible involvement in gene regulation, metabolic adaptation or organellar functions under developmental or environmental conditions [54, 55]. Comparable subcellular localizations have been reported for other DUF-containing proteins, such as members of the DUF231 and DUF266 family, which are involved in cell wall biosynthesis and stress signaling pathways [55, 56]. The wide range of pI values (from strongly acidic to near neutral) for the GhDUF789 proteins could reflect different electrostatic interactions affecting subcellular compartmentalization, protein–protein association or response to local pH environments. Thus, proteins with acidic pI values might be better suited for nucleoplasmic or vacuolar functions, whereas proteins with neutral or basic pI values might be involved in chloroplastic or cytosolic signaling [57, 58]. Similarly, variation in molecular weight across GhDUF789 proteins, particularly the presence of higher MW isoforms (> 100 kDa) in G. barbadense, may indicate domain fusion events or structural extensions that facilitate scaffold functions in vesicle trafficking or stress-associated signaling. These MW and pI patterns appear to correlate with distinct clades or functional subgroups of DUF789 proteins, consistent with the structural diversification observed in motif and exon–intron architectures, and analogous to functional classifications reported in other DUF families [59–61]. These physicochemical features provide functional evidence consistent with the predictions of subcellular localization and GO annotation, supporting the hypothesis that GhDUF789 proteins contribute to a variety of regulatory and stress-responsive pathways in cotton. Consistent predictions across multiple subcellular localization platforms (TargetP, WoLF PSORT and LocTree3 [36, 62, 63]) indicated that several GhDUF789 proteins are likely localized to the nucleus or chloroplasts, suggesting regulatory or organelle-associated roles. These predictions align with the known localization patterns of other DUF-domain proteins involved in stress signaling and development [27, 30]. While experimental validation was not conducted in this study, two representative genes, GhDUF789A-1 and GhDUF789D-3, were prioritized based on their expression profiles and localization signals. These candidates are suitable for targeted functional assays, including GFP-based transient expression, to experimentally confirm subcellular distribution and further elucidate their roles in fibre development and stress response pathways.

Using the protein sequences of G. arboreum, G. barbadense, G. raimondii, G. hirsutum and A. thaliana, a phylogenetic tree was constructed, which was subsequently divided into six different clades. The DUF789 proteins of both diploid and tetraploid Gossypium species were largely clustered with those of A. thaliana. However, a subset of DUF789 proteins from A. thaliana was assigned to a separate clade, suggesting that the functional roles of cotton DUF789 genes may differ from those in A. thaliana. It is widely known that genes within the same phylogenetic clade usually have similar functions [64, 65]. Importantly, the inferred clades were supported by high bootstrap values (≥ 70%), indicating strong statistical reliability of the phylogenetic relationships. This supports the conclusion that gene clusters within each clade reflect true evolutionary conservation and divergence, rather than alignment artefacts.

Analyzing conserved motifs provides crucial insights into the evolutionary dynamics and variation in the functions of gene families [66]. Here, ten conserved motifs were identified among the GhDUF789 proteins, with individual members displaying between one and ten motifs (Fig. 4D, E). This diverse yet structured motif composition suggests that the GhDUF789 proteins may have undergone subtle functional diversification, although a central functional architecture was retained. In contrast, DUF789 proteins in soybean have been reported to have more homogeneous motif patterns as observed by Zeynab et al. (2025) [51]. Structural variations at the exon–intron level are another important factor contributing to gene family evolution, affecting gene expression, alternative splicing and functional plasticity [67]. Our results show that GhDUF789 genes have between three and nine exons (Fig. 4C), a range that is similar to other plant species, such as Arabidopsis and soybean [27, 51]. Remarkably, genes within the same phylogenetic clusters (Fig. 4A) showed largely similar exon–intron organizations, suggesting evolutionary conservation following duplication events. These results suggest that the GhDUF789 gene family has undergone limited but functionally significant intron gain and loss during its evolutionary history, possibly enabling alternative splicing and increasing protein diversity [68].

Examination of the cis-acting regulatory elements within the GhDUF789 promoters revealed a complex landscape of motifs associated with developmental regulation, hormone signaling, photosensitivity and adaptation to abiotic stress (Fig. 5). Among them, motifs such as GARE (gibberellin-responsive), ERE (ethylene-responsive), TCA (salicylic acid-responsive), ABRE (ABA-responsive), ARE (anaerobic induction), G-box and box 4 were strikingly abundant, suggesting that GhDUF789 genes may act as key regulators in the integration of developmental and environmental signaling pathways [69, 70]. The identification of AP2/ERF binding sites, which are known mediators of abiotic stress responses, further supports the possible involvement of GhDUF789 genes in transcriptional networks that respond to stress [71, 72]. In particular, GARE elements have been associated with growth modulation under salt and drought stress conditions [73], and ABRE motifs play a central role in ABA-mediated responses to drought and osmotic stress [74]. The frequent presence of TCA motifs (salicylic acid signaling) and G-box elements, which are known to coordinate light- and stress-dependent gene expression [75, 76], underlines the multifunctional regulatory potential of these promoters. Our results are consistent with the observations of Zhang, Ma [77], who demonstrated the co-regulation of hormonal and environmental signaling pathways via common cis-elements in cotton.

In support of this, our integrated analysis showed a clear correlation between the transcriptional activation of GhDUF789 genes under abiotic stress and the presence of specific stress-responsive cis-elements. For example, GhDUF789A-1, GhDUF789A-12 and GhDUF789D-18, which were strongly upregulated under drought, salinity and cold stress, were enriched with ABRE, MBS (MYB binding site for drought) and DRE (dehydration/cold-responsive element) motifs. In contrast, GhDUF789D-17, which showed negligible expression under all stress conditions, lacked these critical elements. This pattern emphasizes the functional importance of promoter architecture in modulating gene sensitivity to environmental stimuli. Similar relationships have been found in other stress-related gene families in cotton and Arabidopsis, where the density and identity of promoter motifs directly influence transcriptional plasticity [74, 78, 79]. These results highlight the regulatory complexity and adaptive potential of the GhDUF789 gene family in cotton and suggest that certain members, particularly those with enriched cis-element profiles, could be prioritized for functional validation and genetic improvement of stress resilience. The integration of promoter architecture and expression data thus provides a rational framework for the selection of candidate genes in molecular breeding programs aimed at improving the climate adaptability of cotton.

In addition to abiotic stress responses, our findings also suggest that promoter cis-element architecture may influence tissue-specific gene expression during fibre development. Notably, GhDUF789A-1, GhDUF789A-2, and GhDUF789A-8, which exhibited high expression levels during fibre elongation and secondary wall biosynthesis, were enriched in developmental and hormonal regulatory motifs such as CAT-box and ABRE, as well as light-responsive elements (e.g., G-box, Box 4). In contrast, GhDUF789D-17, with minimal fibre expression, lacked such motifs. This correlation supports the hypothesis that cis-regulatory complexity contributes to the spatiotemporal activation of DUF789 genes during key developmental transitions. Similar associations have been reported for other fibre-related gene families in cotton, where promoter enrichment of growth and hormone-related motifs correlates with fibre-stage expression [80–82]. These insights underscore the importance of cis-element profiling in identifying transcriptionally competent genes and prioritizing candidates for molecular breeding programs focused on fiber trait enhancement.

Gene duplication serves as the main mechanism for the expansion and functional diversification of gene families and forms the basis for evolutionary innovations in plant genomes [83]. In cotton, repeated rounds of gene duplication followed by selective gene loss and recombination have characterized the evolutionary development of numerous gene families, including GhDUF789 [84]. Consistent with this, our study revealed that the total number of GhDUF789 genes in G. hirsutum and G. barbadense is lower than the combined number of their diploid ancestors, G. arboreum and G. raimondii, suggesting that gene fractionation accompanied polyploid formation. These trends mirror observations from other cotton gene families where post-polyploidisation dynamics have led to pedigree-specific conservation and loss of genes [29, 85].

The evolutionary pressure on the GhDUF789 family was further investigated by Ka/Ks analysis, which showed that over 90% of the paralogous gene pairs had a Ka/Ks ratio of less than one, indicating a strong influence of purifying selection. This pattern is consistent with previous reports indicating lower evolutionary pressure and stabilizing selection in the allotetraploid cotton genomes compared to their diploid ancestors [86, 87]. Syntenic analyses revealed extensive collinearity between the GhDUF789 loci in the A and D subgenomes, highlighting the substantial contributions of both ancestors to the current genetic architecture of upland cotton [88]. Taken together, these results suggest that the GhDUF789 gene family was predominantly shaped by purifying selection associated with differential gene retention after polyploidization, maintaining core functions while allowing subtle diversification within the cotton lineage.

The predicted protein–protein interaction network within the gene family offers valuable insights into their potential functional relationships and evolutionary conservation [89]. Most GhDUF789 proteins exhibited homology-based associations with proteins containing DUF789 domains or with proteins of unknown function. This pattern is consistent with the observation that many DUF (Domain of Unknown Function) proteins are increasingly recognized as critical players in plant stress adaptation and developmental regulation, despite their initial annotation gaps [6].
