Structural modelling revealed that GhDUF789 proteins predominantly have an architecture characterized by a relatively low alpha-helix content and predominantly random turns. Proteins with such flexible, coil-rich structures are thought to facilitate dynamic interactions and adaptive conformational changes under stress conditions, supporting their role in flexible regulatory complexes [90].

In addition, remarkable differences in the composition of the secondary structure of GhDUF789 members were observed. Some proteins exhibited more ordered, helical features, while others showed a higher degree of structural disorder. Such structural diversity within gene families is often associated with functional divergence, allowing proteins to take on specialized or flexible roles [91, 92]. This diversity suggests possible functional divergence within the gene family, where certain GhDUF789 proteins may fulfil more static structural or catalytic roles, while others may act as flexible scaffolds or signaling adaptors in environmental stress responses. Proteins that are enriched in intrinsically disordered regions have been specifically implicated in dynamic regulatory processes and rapid adaptation under stress conditions in plants [93]. Overall, the combination of predicted PPI networks and 3D structural models suggests that the GhDUF789 family, despite its limited functional characterization, may represent a dynamically adaptable group of proteins that play diverse roles in cotton developmental processes and stress responses [30]. Prediction of protein-protein interactions (PPI) performed with STRING v12.0 [39] and interolog-based inference approaches [94, 95] revealed several interaction partners of GhDUF789 proteins, including mitochondrial ribosomal components and stress-associated proteins. These computationally derived interactions provide a meaningful basis for hypothesis generation and functional prioritization, particularly in the context of cross-genome gene family analyses, where direct empirical validation is often limited [96]. Although experimental PPI validation is beyond the scope of the current study, future efforts will focus on confirming key interactions using yeast two-hybrid and co-immunoprecipitation assays to elucidate the mechanistic role of GhDUF789 proteins in fibre development and stress adaptation.

MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are crucial regulators of several biological processes in plants, including metabolism, development and responses to environmental stress [97–99]. In Arabidopsis, miRNA-mediated silencing pathways, such as trans-acting small interfering RNAs (tasiRNAs), have been implicated in the regulation of genes involved in abiotic stress responses [100]. In this study, nine putative ghr-miRNAs were predicted to target multiple GhDUF789 genes, primarily via cleavage or translation inhibition mechanisms. Among these, the ghr-miR414 family members, targeting GhDUF789A-4, GhDUF789D-16 and GhDUF789D-19 have been identified, highlighting their potential regulatory importance. In particular, miR414 has already been linked to drought stress response in rice [101] and barley [102], disease resistance in aubergine (Solanum melongena L.) [103], development of pollen in Brassica rapa [104], floral development in Hypericum perforatum [105], fibre development in cotton [106] and salinity stress tolerance [107]. In addition, ghr-miR396a was predicted to target several GhDUF789 genes (GhDUF789A−2, GhDUF789A−5, GhDUF789D−14, GhDUF789D−17 and GhDUF789D−22), predominantly by cleavage, suggesting that it is involved in the post-transcriptional regulation of GhDUF789 family members. miR396 has been observed to be involved in stress responses, including drought and cold tolerance, mediated via an abscisic acid (ABA)-dependent signaling pathway [108, 109]. Overall, these results indicate that the identified ghr-miRNAs may be responsible for the adaptation of cotton to various environmental stresses by modulating the expression of GhDUF789 genes. Nevertheless, additional experimental validation is essential to elucidate the specific functional roles of these miRNA–GhDUF789 regulatory modules.

GO enrichment analysis of GhDUF789 family members revealed significant associations with clathrin-mediated endocytosis, vesicle budding and phosphatidylinositol binding activities. These biological processes are an integral part of membrane transport, which has an essential role in plant growth, development and adaptation to stress [110–112]. The enrichment of clathrin coat assembly and SNARE binding termini suggests that GhDUF789 proteins may contribute to vesicle formation and intracellular transport, processes known to modulate responses to environmental stimuli [113]. Similar functions have been reported from Arabidopsis and rice, where clathrin-associated signaling pathways have been linked to hormonal signaling and abiotic stress tolerance [114, 115]. Therefore, it is plausible that GhDUF789 members act at the interface between membrane dynamics and stress resistance in cotton. Further functional validation will be necessary to clarify their exact role.

The results from the expression profiling show that GhDUF789 genes have unique and constitutive expression patterns in different cotton tissues and in response to different abiotic conditions. Analysis of expression in different tissues and developmental stages revealed different patterns, with one subset showing significant upregulation during fibre development. In particular, GhDUF789A−1, GhDUF789A−2 and GhDUF789A−8 showed progressively increased expression during fiber elongation and maturation stages, suggesting that they are involved in secondary cell wall deposition - a hypothesis further strengthened by their GO annotations and promoter motif composition. Similar fiber-specific expression profiles were found in other DUF gene families, such as GhDUF288 [116, 117] and GhDUF1117 [118]. Conversely, other GhDUF789 genes showed tissue-specific expression patterns with preferential accumulation in organs such as the root, stem or floral structures.

Different expression profiles were also observed under different abiotic stress factors such as heat, cold, salinity and drought. In particular, GhDUF789D−20 and GhDUF789D−14 were highly upregulated under drought stress, suggesting a possible role in stress tolerance mechanisms. These observations are in tandem with previous findings, such as those of MA et al. [22], who reported that OsDUF6 was more highly expressed in salt-stressed leaves than in irrigated plants. Similarly, Jayaraman et al. [119] demonstrated that DUF740 promoted root length, thereby improving drought resistance and fruit retention. Although different gene families were studied, the pattern of stress-responsive upregulation observed in GhDUF789 genes is consistent with these previous reports. In addition, FPKM-based expression analysis revealed significant tissue-specific variation among GhDUF789 members. For instance, GhDUF789A−6 and GhDUF789A−11 exhibited relatively high expression levels across multiple tissues, whereas others, such as GhDUF789A−10 and GhDUF789A−5, displayed restricted expression confined to specific organs. Analogous expression trends have been reported for DUF family members, such as DUF668, which showed predominant expression in leaves [30], and DUF288, which was broadly expressed across fibre tissue [116]. Taken together, our results demonstrate that GhDUF789 genes constitute a structurally conserved yet functionally diversified family, contributing to critical developmental and adaptive processes in cotton. Their potential involvement in fibre quality traits and abiotic stress tolerance makes them promising candidates for molecular breeding initiatives, aimed at improving cotton productivity and resilience under increasingly adverse climatic conditions.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The DUF789 gene family in four cotton species was thoroughly identified and characterized throughout the genome in this investigation. A total of 91 DUF789 genes were recognized, showing conserved domain structures but divergent exon–intron architectures, motif compositions and chromosomal distributions, suggesting functional diversification after polyploidisation. Phylogenetic and synteny analyses suggested that segmental and tandem duplications contributed substantially to family expansion, with purifying selection acting as the main evolutionary force, although cases of positive selection were also detected. Cis-acting element analysis revealed that GhDUF789 promoters are enriched in regulatory motifs associated with hormonal signaling, developmental processes and abiotic stress responses. Expression profiling revealed that several GhDUF789 genes are differentially expressed during fibre development and under drought, salt, cold and heat stress, suggesting that they play a central role in fibre maturation and environmental adaptation. Protein–protein interaction predictions and GO enrichment supported the possible involvement of DUF789 proteins in vesicle transport and stress-related cellular processes. Overall, this study provides the first detailed insights into the structure, evolution and potential biological functions of DUF789 genes in cotton, providing a valuable resource for future functional studies and for advancing molecular breeding to improve cotton fibre quality and stress tolerance.
